description.narrative: The project ‘Sustainable Arsenic Mitigation (SASMIT), Community driven initiatives to target arsenic safe groundwater as sustainable mitigation strategy´includes two major components: i) a global component for advocacy, awareness raising, capacity building, exchange of information, conceptualisation of the mitigation option and replication-trials for validation of the option for other developing countries with elevated levels of geogenic As in groundwater, and ii) a multidisciplinary action research in Matlab, Bangladesh including hydrogeological investigations, field implementation, generation of knowledge, capacity building based on participatory approaches, monitoring, management and establishment of water safety plan for the promoted option in collaboration with the with local government and other stakeholders. For the Action research in Matlab, NGOF and Dhaka University in collaboration with KTH-Ramböll carried out various activities planned for the fourth year of the project. To provide community driven option for safe water as arsenic mitigation option, assessment of hydrogeological characteristics and social conditions were evaluated with emphasize on the distribution of hard-core poor and access to As-safe water, and these assessments were used to optimize the location for installation of safe water wells. Based on the knowledge gained during first three years of the project, 300 safe wells have been installed in the project area out of which 245 wells were installed during year 4. The installation plan was modified during the third annual review and instead of drilling safe wells in the off-white sediments, safe wells were installed at the intermediate depth aquifer (˜ 120 m) which was found white in most cases for targeting water with low arsenic and manganese. This was the first time in Bangladesh the intermediate depth have been explored in a systematic way and found good aquifer with acceptable water quality. The wells installed are termed as "IDTW", intermediate deep tube wells, which is a new option for safe water in the country. Limited replication trails in four upazilas outside Matlab also proved the viability of wider application of the action research-based ‘SASMIT Strategy’ for installing safe wells considering hydrogeological, hydrogeochemical, existing safe water coverage, capability of local drillers and socio-economic conditions of the target population. Safe water access has been significantly improved by the addition of new community wells. This strategy will be communicated to the policy level in Bangladesh and can be widely replicated by implementers of safe water supplies in Bangladesh. A tool has been conceptualised for guiding the local drillers in order to install safe wells in and outside the areas. Thus, two strategies have emerged through the SASMIT project; i) the SASMIT Colour strategy for identification and targeting of low As groundwater and ii) the SASMIT IDTW strategy for identification of intermediate deep aquifer for targeting low As- and Mn groundwater. The SASMIT Colour strategy is represent the original project concept and hypothesis and can be considered successful regarding As but not with respect to high Mn concentrations.
